hours_text:
# Visit

## **Hours & Directions**

### OPEN Tuesday – Saturday  
10 AM – 5 PM  
**Free Admission**

Closed Juneteenth, July 4th, Thanksgiving, and   
December 25th – January 1st.   
Closed 2 – 5 PM on December 16th.

#### **4848 MAIN STREET,****HOUSTON, TX 77002**

### 

### **LOCATION**

Houston Center for Contemporary Craft is located in the Houston Museum District at 4848 Main Street, two blocks south of Highway 59/69, near Rosedale Street.

### **FREE Parking**

HCCC offers free parking in our lot behind the building, off Rosedale and Travis Streets. 

### **Accessibility**

Accessible parking spaces are available in the free parking lot behind the building, off Rosedale and Travis Streets. To request accommodations for special needs, please contact María-Elisa Heg at [mheg@crafthouston.org](http://web.archive.org/web/20251214193601/mailto:mheg@crafthouston.org)

Directions

**BY METRO RAIL**  
From Downtown or the Texas Medical Center HCCC is approximately three blocks south of the Wheeler Transit Center station and eight blocks north of the Museum District Station. [www.RideMETRO.org/MuseumDistrict](http://web.archive.org/web/20251214193601/http://www.ridemetro.org/MuseumDistrict)

**FROM MONTROSE BOULEVARD**  
Turn east on Chelsea. Turn left on Travis. The parking lot is on the right, past the stop sign at Rosedale. Enter through the back door.

**FROM HWY 59, NORTHBOUND**  
Take the Main Street exit. Turn right on Main St, right on Rosedale (at Texas State Optical), ...

[ ](/web/20260107020713/http://web.archive.org/screenshot/https://crafthouston.org/ "screenshot")

About this capture

COLLECTED BY

Organization: [Archive Team](https://archive.org/details/archiveteam)

Formed in 2009, the Archive Team (not to be confused with the archive.org Archive-It Team) is a rogue archivist collective dedicated to saving copies of rapidly dying or deleted websites for the sake of history and digital heritage. The group is 100% composed of volunteers and interested parties, and has expanded into a large amount of related projects for saving online and digital history. 

History is littered with hundreds of conflicts over the future of a community, group, location or business that were "resolved" when one of the parties stepped ahead and destroyed what was there. With the original point of contention destroyed, the debates would fall to the wayside. Archive Team believes that by duplicated condemned data, the conversation and debate can continue, as well as the richness and insight gained by keeping the materials. Our projects have ranged ...
